channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Europe the Unready
item.description: The hope for a growing European unity has suffered setbacks amid terrorism, the refugee crisis and financial challenges.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN

item.title: Gunmen Strike Shiite Mosque in Bangladesh
item.description: Gunmen opened fire during evening prayers at the mosque, killing one person and wounding three, in the second recent attack on Bangladesh’s tiny Shiite population.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: North and South Korea to Hold High-Level Talks Next Month
item.description: The talks, to be led by a vice minister from each side, are intended to ease tensions and improve relations on the divided Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Moldova: 13 Accused of Plotting Attacks
item.description: The Moldovan police said Thursday that they had detained 13 people suspected of being members of a paramilitary group accused of planning to attack cities.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cellphone Recording Leads to Arrest of Brazilian Senator on Obstruction Charges
item.description: Delcídio do Amaral, an ally of President Dilma Rousseff, was charged with impeding an investigation into Brazil’s state-owned oil company.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: River Polluted After Dam Burst
item.description: Illegal levels of arsenic and mercury polluted a river in the days after a dam burst at an iron ore mine this month.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Anti-Insurgency Goal Extended
item.description: Nigeria’s military cannot meet the president’s December deadline to crush Boko Haram’s Islamist uprising.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: U.S. Condemns a Killing
item.description: The local activist, Luis Díaz, a leader of the opposition Democratic Action party in Guárico State, was shot at a public meeting on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Number of Migrants Illegally Crossing Rio Grande Rises Sharply
item.description: Once again, smugglers are bringing hundreds of women and children each day to the Mexican banks of the river and sending them across in rafts.
item.dc:creator: JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: United States Border Patrol agents detained undocumented immigrants after they crossed into the United States from Mexico near McAllen, Tex., in August.

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Priest Faces Abuse Inquiry
item.description: A high-ranking priest was suspended while the church investigated allegations that he had sexually abused a girl over an eight-year period.
item.dc:creator: GENE PALUMBO

item.title: For Japanese-Americans, Resistance to Syrian Refugees Recalls Long-Ago Fears
item.description: The dark memories of seven decades ago have bubbled to the surface in recent weeks for many people who were sent to Japanese internment camps.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JOHN ELIGON
item.media:description: Yuka Fujikura and her brother Homer Yasui recently. During World War II, they were sent to one of the biggest internment camps in Tule Lake, Calif.

item.title: Canada’s New Leadership Reverses Course on Climate Change
item.description: The new prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has moved climate-change policy to the top of the country’s political agenda after it spent nearly a decade as an afterthought.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with high school students in Ottawa after an information session on climate change.

item.title: Britain Adopts Black Friday With an All-American Frenzy
item.description: Some retailers are trying to dial back, because for a nation that prides itself on decorum, last year was ugly; or, a typical American Black Friday.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Shoppers wrestling over a television on Black Friday at an Asda superstore in Wembley, North London, last year. Asda said it would not participate in this year's Black Friday shopping frenzy.

item.title: China Bars Anastasia Lin, Miss World Canada (and Rights Advocate)
item.description: Miss Canada, Anastasia Lin, was denied a visa to attend the international pageant, apparently because she is outspoken about human-rights abuses in the country of her birth.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miss Canada, Anastasia Lin, was denied a visa to participate in the Miss World contest in China.

item.title: Portugal’s New Premier Takes Office, Facing Financial Balancing Act
item.description: The new government of António Costa, the Socialist leader and a former mayor of Lisbon, brings to an end to almost two months of political instability.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Kremlin Cutting Economic Links With the Turks
item.description: Russia was looking at ways to curb commercial ties and investment projects, possibly including the deal to build a gas pipeline through Turkey.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephane De Sakutin
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, and President François Hollande of France met in Moscow on Thursday.

item.title: Pope Francis, in Kenya, Delivers Message of Humility
item.description: The pope also said the need for dialogue between religions was “essential” during a meeting on Thursday on his first official trip to Africa.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Catholic priests and worshipers on Thursday attending a Mass by Pope Francis in Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimea Power Outage
item.description: As Crimean Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists prevented repair crews from getting to downed electricity pylons, Kiev closed its airspace to Russian planes and Moscow cut off gas supplies to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A single light illuminated a room Wednesday during a blackout in the city of Simferopol, Crimea.

item.title: China Retools Its Military With a First Overseas Outpost in Djibouti
item.description: China said a facility in the East African nation would serve to resupply its naval ships taking part in antipiracy missions.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A People's Liberation Army training drill near Beijing last year. China said on Thursday that it would build a logistics facility in Djibouti, in a sign of the growing reach of its navy.

item.title: Britain and Germany Test Support for Stronger Steps Against ISIS
item.description: The French president this week had made efforts to rally his allies against the threat posed by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain released on Thursday a 36-page document, detailing a plan to try to tackle the threat posed by the Islamic State diplomatically as well as militarily.
